title: Forth Wanderers F.C.
text:
Forth Wanderers Football Club are a Scottish <a href="football%20%28soccer%29">football</a> club based in the village of <a href="Forth%2C%20Lanarkshire">Forth</a>, <a href="South%20Lanarkshire">South Lanarkshire</a>. Formed in 1904 they compete in the and play in red strips with a white trim with a second strip of all black.
History.
Since 1934 they have played at Kingshill Park in the village, however they have had to share with <a href="Carluke%20Rovers%20F.C.">Carluke Rovers</a> for a spell and play on a public park in <a href="Carnwath">Carnwath</a> when this ground proved unusable. The team's first games were played at Pleasure Park before the Wanderers moved to Hie Dyke in 1929. It was 5 years later until they moved to what is their current home, Kingshill Park in 1934.
Forth have supplied two Scottish international goalkeepers in <a href="George%20Wood%20%28footballer%29">George Wood</a> and <a href="Robert%20Douglas%20%28footballer%29">Rab Douglas</a>. <a href="Rangers%20F.C.">Rangers</a> legend <a href="Willie%20Waddell">Willie Waddell</a> came from the village and starred for the team in his pre-Ibrox days.
Wanderers reached the semi-finals of the <a href="Scottish%20Junior%20Cup">Scottish Junior Cup</a> in 1981 and their home quarter-final tie versus <a href="East%20Kilbride%20Thistle%20F.C.">East Kilbride Thistle</a> attracted a record crowd of 2,324.
The team's co-managers are Graham Cairns and Thomas Devine.
